Detailed Description

This class is a predefined network using the FeedForward Backpropagation algorithm.

class VVNetwork, is a template for the FeedForward Backpropagation algortihm. It supports networks, having any number of layers. The network supports different transferfunctions.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

VVNetwork::VVNetwork (  int  ,
  ...
) 
 

Constructor, uses ellipsis.

The constructor follows the follwing format:

first argument is the number of layers(int).
The second,third...(n-3)th arguments indicate the number of neurons(int) for concecutive layers.
The third last argument is the learning rate(double).
The second last argument is the momentum value(double).
The last argument is the number of iterations to be executed.

VVNetwork::~VVNetwork (   )  [inline]
 

The destructor, it frees all the dynamically allocated memory

void VVNetwork::VVnetwork_train (   ) 
 

Trains the network with the specified data.

The function is used to train the network for a single iteration. It calls VVFeedForward(int&) and VVBackPropagate(int&).

Depreciated function

void VVNetwork::VVreadinputfrom (  char *   ) 
 

This function extracts input and stores it in memory from the specified file.

void VVNetwork::VVreadoutputfrom (  char *   ) 
 

This function extracts the actual output and stores it in memory from the specfied file.

int VVNetwork::VVsave_network (  char  []  ) 
 

This function saves the network.

This function saves all the vital characterestics of a network such as the number of layers, the number of neurons per layer, the weights, etc. This is stored in a binary format for ease of saving and loading. Hence do not attempt to a saved network, or it may end up curropted.

void VVNetwork::VVSimulatedAnnealing (  double   ) 
 

This function is in research stages. Do not use.

This function tests the network with the specified testfile.

VVLayer* VVNetwork::layers [protected]
 

This is a pointer to create any number of layers.

The network consists of parallel layers with interconnections between each layer. Input is fed through the branches of various layers until it reaches the output layer.

double*** VVNetwork::weights [protected]
 

This is a very important concept in Neural Networks.

The weights tell a neuron A, recieving input from neuron B, just how much importance, neuron A, must give to the input it recieves from neuron B. This is done by multiplying the input recieved with the weight.
The Three dimensional weights indicate:
The 1st dimension : It indicates the connection between the nth and (n+1)th layer.
The 2nd dimension : It indicates the ith neuron in the nth layer. The 3rd dimension : It indicates the jth neuron in the (n+1)th layer.

double*** VVNetwork::xerox_weights [protected]
 

A copy of the weight matrix for use in intermediate calculations
